meta.title: OmniVanity: Multi-Chain Vanity Wallet Generator (GUI + CLI) — Build Game Plan
meta.primary_goal: Ship a GPU-first, premium-feel Windows application (plus CLI) that can generate vanity addresses across major chains, starting with ETH/EVM + BTC/LTC, and scaling to 100+ coins via a coin-definition plugin system.

confirmed.ux_priority: Ultra-modern GUI; advanced controls hidden by default; professional EXE/installer quality.
confirmed.performance_priority: GPU-first, with automatic CPU fallback or CPU+GPU only when it measurably increases throughput.
confirmed.observability: In-GUI performance stats: addr/s, key/s, MH/s-equivalent where applicable; difficulty + ETA/probability.

not_yet_confirmed: GPU vendor targets (NVIDIA CUDA vs OpenCL vs wgpu/DirectX/Vulkan)
Exact address types to support per chain (BTC: legacy/P2SH/bech32/taproot; LTC: legacy/bech32; EVM: checksum rules)

assumptions_to_unblock_execution.assumption: Windows is the primary target for v1; Linux builds are optional in later phases.
assumptions_to_unblock_execution.reason: User requested EXE + Windows installer focus.

assumptions_to_unblock_execution.assumption: No network calls are required for core vanity generation; coin lists ship as files and can be updated via importing 'coin packs'.
assumptions_to_unblock_execution.reason: Avoid reliance on external APIs, improve determinism and security posture.

assumptions_to_unblock_execution.assumption: Licensing risk is handled by re-implementing functionality from scratch (feature parity), not copying GPL/AGPL code into the new codebase.
assumptions_to_unblock_execution.reason: Key upstream engines (VanitySearch GPL-3.0; vanitygen-plusplus AGPL-3.0) can contaminate distribution if directly embedded.

assumptions_to_unblock_execution.assumption: GPU backend strategy will be layered: (1) wgpu compute for broad coverage, (2) optional CUDA backend for NVIDIA performance, (3) optional OpenCL backend where practical.
assumptions_to_unblock_execution.reason: User wants GPU-first *and* broad device coverage for normies.

assumptions_to_unblock_execution.assumption: First deliverable is a proof-of-concept that looks like a finished product and supports ETH/EVM + BTC + LTC with high-fidelity stats and exports.
assumptions_to_unblock_execution.reason: User explicitly called it a proof-of-concept demonstrating agent thoroughness.

must_extract_features: GPU-first design with CPU assist and multi-GPU support
CUDA optimizations (inline PTX), tunable GPU grid size
High-performance secp256k1 arithmetic: fixed-size math, fast modular inversion, fast modular multiplication
Uses elliptic curve properties to generate more keys per iteration
CPU-optimized hashing (SSE SHA256 + RIPEMD160)
Supports P2PKH, P2SH, and Bech32 address types
BIP38-style passphrase-derived base key (-s) and passphrase+secure seed (-ps), pbkdf2_hmac_sha512
Split-key vanity address support
Operational considerations: keep one CPU core for GPU/CPU exchange to maximize throughput
notes: Use as a feature reference only; do not copy GPL code into proprietary distribution.

repo_feature_inventory.scope: Vanity generator supporting 100+ cryptocurrencies (CPU + OpenCL variants)
must_extract_features: Supports 100+ cryptocurrencies with coin selection (e.g., -C LIST / -C ETH)
Displays difficulty, throughput (Mkey/s), total keys tested, probability, and 50% ETA
BTC support includes legacy and modern formats: p2wpkh (bech32) and p2tr (taproot)
ETH vanity wallet generation and vanity contract address generation (format flag for contract)
OpenCL GPU acceleration via oclvanitygen++
Includes key conversion utility (keyconv) and supports split-key generation workflow (-P pubkey) with PrivkeyPart recombination
Includes 'Solving Bitcoin Puzzles' modes (range/bit-limited search) using parameters like -Z base key and -l bit length
Multiple executables (vanitygen++, oclvanitygen++, keyconv, oclvanityminer)
Build supports standard make + 'make all' for GPU binaries and a nix-build pathway
notes: AGPL is incompatible with many closed-source distribution plans; treat as a feature + test vector source.
Upstream README documents puzzle-mode (-Z/-l) and split-key workflow with keyconv (-P / PrivkeyPart recombination).

repo_feature_inventory.scope: Bitcoin + Ethereum vanity generator with regex + GPU (wgpu) + TUI
must_extract_features: Regex pattern matching (not only prefixes)
Multiple address formats: BTC P2PKH and P2WPKH; Ethereum 0x
GPU acceleration via wgpu (Vulkan/Metal/DX12/OpenGL backends)
Parallel CPU scanning (rayon)
Interactive TUI with real-time statistics
Range scanning for Bitcoin puzzle challenges
Data-provider hooks for puzzle/bounty integration
JSON output mode and minimal output mode
notes: wgpu approach is useful for cross-vendor GPU-first defaults on Windows.
README indicates GPU is enabled by default and can be disabled via --no-gpu; supports regex patterns and multiple formats.

must_extract_features: Generate multiple addresses per run
Multi-core support
Vanity contract address support
Log-to-file
Checksum-based vanity (EIP-55 style matching)
notes: Repo is archived; still a good feature reference and test vector generator.
Archived upstream; treat as reference + test vectors, not a dependency.

Difficulty estimate and 'prefix feasibility' validation concepts from vanitygen lineage
Case-insensitive option patterns (where supported) as reference
notes: Reference only; use for test vectors and behavioral parity checks.
Legacy C vanitygen variant; useful as reference and for test vectors.

Simple CPU-only scan loop to cross-check correctness vs Rust/C++ core
notes: Reference only; not a core dependency.
Go implementation; useful as reference and for cross-checking address derivation.

must_extract_features: Prefix feasibility/difficulty estimation logic as reference
Exact-prefix vs regex modes and performance expectations
Keyconv-style utility patterns (address version overrides) as reference
notes: Reference only; do not embed unless licensing posture is intentionally copyleft.
Canonical 'vanitygen' reference; useful for historical behavior and prefix feasibility/difficulty logic.

must_extract_features: Windows build layout, dependency notes, and CUDA/OpenCL SDK integration patterns (as documented by port)
Installer/runtime packaging lessons learned

required: One-click 'Start' with sane defaults (GPU-first auto), minimal jargon
Chain selector with search, favorites, and presets
Address type selector per chain (BTC: legacy/P2SH/bech32/taproot; EVM: checksum mode toggle)
Real-time stats: keys/s, addresses/s, difficulty, probability to hit by time horizon, 50% ETA
Device panel (Advanced): GPU list, backend (wgpu/CUDA/OpenCL), per-device enable/disable, auto-tune
Export panel: copy buttons + file export + optional encrypted export
Safety UX: clear warnings for 'too-hard' patterns, estimated time, and secure key handling tips
nice_to_have: Integrated TUI-like live console for power users
QR generation for address, optional for private key only when explicitly enabled

required: Headless generation with identical core engine as GUI
Machine-readable JSON output + minimal human output
Batch mode: pattern lists file, multiple chains, multiple formats
Deterministic 'benchmark' command to pick fastest backend

multi_chain_support: EVM family (ETH, BNB Chain, Polygon, Arbitrum, Optimism, Base, etc.) — address derivation identical; chain ID is metadata
UTXO/secp256k1 family (BTC, LTC, DOGE-like variants) — param-driven version bytes and bech32 HRPs
Ed25519 family (Solana, Stellar, etc.) — future extension (already present in upstream feature sets)
pattern_matching: checksum-aware matching for EVM (EIP-55), with modes: lowercase-only, checksum-exact
generation_modes: split-key / partial-key generation (advanced security mode) for supported chains
range scan / constrained scan modes (puzzle mode) for BTC-like chains (Advanced)
performance: CPU-only fallback if GPU not available
CPU+GPU hybrid only if benchmark proves speedup (auto decision)
outputs: Extended formats (where applicable): compressed/uncompressed pubkey, WIF compressed flag, etc.
JSON export schema stable across chains

reason: Deterministic high-performance core shared by GUI and CLI
Safer memory handling for key material with Rust
Excellent FFI surface to both Tauri (Rust) and Python (if needed)
modules: crypto-primitives (secp256k1, ed25519, keccak, sha256, ripemd160, bech32/base58, pbkdf2)
gpu-backends (wgpu first; optional cuda; optional opencl)

cons: Web UI stack adds frontend complexity

option_b.tech: PySide6/QML frontend + Rust core via FFI
pros: Closer to user’s existing Python GUI workflow
cons: Packaging heavier; harder to feel 'native-premium' without extra work

gui.recommendation: Option A (Tauri) for 'looks like a product team shipped it'.

tier_1_default.why: Cross-vendor GPU support and simpler 'normie' install story; aligns with vgen feature set.

tier_2_optional.why: Best-in-class secp256k1 throughput on NVIDIA; aligns with VanitySearch design goals.

tier_3_optional.why: Compatibility with AMD/older stacks; aligns with vanitygen-plusplus OpenCL variants.

auto_tuning: First-run benchmark: small sample runs per backend/device to choose default
Per-chain kernel specialization (EVM keccak vs BTC pipeline)

coin_packs.format: JSON definition files shipped with the app
content: address formats supported and their parameters (version bytes, HRPs, checksums)
coin_packs.starting_source: Use vanitygen-plusplus coin coverage as a completeness reference (feature parity), re-implemented in our own coin-pack schema.

dependency_policy.rule: For any third-party dependency (even permissive), pin version/commit and vendor minimal surface area.

phases.name: Requirements Lock + Feature Parity Inventory
phases.objective: Freeze v1 scope, build a zero-miss feature inventory from upstream repos, and define acceptance criteria that match the 'premium product' requirement.
deliverables: Feature matrix (repo -> features -> implementation notes)
Coin family taxonomy + coin-pack schema draft
UX wireflows for Simple vs Advanced, and CLI command map
Security posture doc (key handling, RNG, export encryption, safe-mode split-key)
Build/packaging decision (Tauri vs PySide6) and repo scaffolding plan
tasks: Extract feature list from VanitySearch (CUDA/multi-GPU, BIP38 passphrase modes, address types, split-key, tuning)
Extract feature list from vanitygen-plusplus (100+ coins, OpenCL binaries, keyconv, split-key workflow, puzzle modes, contract vanity, stats formatting)
Extract feature list from vgen (regex, wgpu, CPU rayon, TUI stats, JSON/min output, puzzle integration hooks)
Extract feature list from VanityEth (multi-core, contract vanity, checksum vanity, file logging)
Unify into one requirements doc with MUST/SHOULD/COULD priorities
Define v1 supported chains: EVM (ETH/BNB/etc.) + BTC + LTC
Define v1 address types: BTC legacy + bech32 + taproot; LTC legacy + bech32; EVM checksum modes
acceptance_criteria: No 'unknowns' remain for v1 scope; any remaining decisions are explicitly marked and owned.
A junior dev can implement from the spec without asking what flags or modes mean.
risks: Licensing: directly embedding GPL/AGPL code forces open-sourcing; mitigate via clean-room reimplementation.
GPU scope creep: too many backends at once; mitigate by wgpu-first, then CUDA as performance upgrade.

phases.name: Core Engine MVP (CPU) + CLI First
phases.objective: Stand up the new codebase with a CPU-only engine that supports ETH/EVM vanity and emits stable JSON outputs and stats.
deliverables: engine-core with cancellation, rate stats, checkpointing stubs
pattern-engine: prefix/suffix/contains + optional regex (flagged off by default)
EVM chain adapter: key -> pubkey -> keccak -> address; checksum mode support
CLI: `generate`, `benchmark`, `list-chains`, `validate-pattern`, `export-schema`
JSON output schema v1 + golden test vectors
tasks: Implement secure RNG (OS RNG) and key material zeroization
Implement keccak-256 and EIP-55 checksum formatting
Implement multi-thread CPU scan with work-stealing
Implement live stats + difficulty/probability estimator matching vanitygen++ style outputs
Implement file logging (session logs + results log)
acceptance_criteria: CLI generates ETH vanity addresses with prefix match at correct probability and correct checksum formatting.
Throughput scales with CPU cores; stats are stable and accurate within +/-5% on a 10s sample.
JSON output is parseable and consistent across runs.

phases.name: GPU Acceleration for EVM (wgpu first) + Auto Benchmarking
phases.objective: Make GPU the default engine path for EVM vanity (fast win), with automated backend selection and CPU fallback.
deliverables: wgpu compute kernel for EVM pipeline (batch keccak + address compare)
Scheduler that can run GPU-only or GPU+CPU (only if benchmark says faster)
Device enumeration + auto-tune of batch sizes/workgroups
In-engine benchmark harness producing a 'best backend' profile per chain
tasks: Design GPU kernel API: input seeds -> derived candidate privkeys -> compute addresses -> match mask
Implement CPU-side prefiltering vs GPU-only path decision
Implement cancellation, progress, and match extraction without stalling GPU
Add CLI: `benchmark --chain EVM` and export benchmark JSON
acceptance_criteria: On a midrange GPU, EVM vanity throughput exceeds CPU-only by a clear margin.
If GPU is unavailable, engine seamlessly falls back to CPU with identical outputs.
Hybrid mode is only enabled when it measurably increases throughput.
risks: GPU driver variability; mitigate with wgpu feature probing and robust fallbacks.

phases.name: BTC/LTC CPU Support (UTXO family) + Address Types
phases.objective: Add BTC and LTC vanity generation on CPU with correct address formatting and export formats.
deliverables: secp256k1 key derivation + pubkey serialization
BTC hashing pipeline: SHA256 + RIPEMD160 + Base58Check and bech32/bech32m as needed
Address type support: legacy (P2PKH), P2SH (optional), bech32 (P2WPKH), taproot (P2TR)
LTC parameters: version bytes + HRPs; legacy + bech32
Export formats: BTC/LTC WIF + hex; compressed/uncompressed where applicable
tasks: Implement base58check + bech32 encoding
Implement taproot address encoding (bech32m) for BTC
Implement pattern matching on encoded address string + optional raw-byte matching for speed
Add split-key workflow scaffolding (CPU version) for BTC-like chains
acceptance_criteria: Generated BTC/LTC addresses validate against known libraries and match expected format rules.
Exported WIF keys import successfully in reference wallets (team should test with offline tools).

phases.name: GPU Acceleration for secp256k1 (BTC/LTC) — CUDA then optional OpenCL
phases.objective: Bring BTC/LTC into the GPU-first world with a real throughput jump, borrowing optimization concepts from VanitySearch.
deliverables: CUDA backend for secp256k1 scalar multiplication optimized for vanity searching
Multi-GPU support with per-device grid auto-tune
CPU assist pipeline tuned for GPU throughput (keep one core for dispatch/IO)
Optional OpenCL backend (if team capacity allows)
tasks: Kernel design: batch scalar multiply -> pubkey -> hash -> encode/prefix compare (optimize compare before full encode where possible)
Implement modular arithmetic optimizations analogous to VanitySearch feature set (fast inversion/mul, fixed-size math)
Implement grid/workgroup auto-tuning and persistence per device
Implement safe passphrase-seeded generation mode (BIP38-like) as an option
acceptance_criteria: GPU BTC/LTC throughput materially outperforms CPU baseline on supported NVIDIA GPUs.
Multi-GPU scaling is near-linear for 2 GPUs on the same host (within expected PCIe limits).
risks: CUDA-only may exclude AMD users; mitigate with wgpu/OpenCL roadmap and clear device messaging.

phases.name: Split-Key / Safe-Mode + Puzzle/Range Modes (Advanced)
phases.objective: Implement advanced modes seen in upstream: split-key vanity generation, puzzle/range scanning, and secure UX.
deliverables: Split-key generation for BTC-like and EVM (offset/seed style where possible)
Range scan / constrained scan modes for BTC-like chains
Import/export of partial key material, with strong validation and guardrails
Advanced UI toggles + documentation
tasks: Implement split-key flows analogous to vanitygen++ (-P) and VanitySearch split-key concept
Implement EVM safe-mode akin to profanity2 approach (seed+offset)
Implement puzzle mode parameters (range start/end, stride, bit-length) and ensure it is opt-in and clearly labeled
acceptance_criteria: Split-key workflow can be completed end-to-end without exposing the final private key to the 'worker' machine.
Puzzle/range mode produces deterministic search behavior given the same inputs.

phases.name: Ultra-Modern GUI + Product Polish
phases.objective: Deliver the premium look: polished GUI, onboarding, safe defaults, and pro-grade export UX.
deliverables: Tauri desktop app (recommended) with signed installer
Simple mode flow: chain -> pattern -> start -> result
Advanced settings drawer for devices, regex, split-key, export encryption
Session history + saved presets + favorites
Live charts/graphs optional (throughput over time)
Crash-safe logging and self-diagnostics bundle export
acceptance_criteria: A normie can generate a vanity address without seeing 'GPU backend' jargon.
A power user can reproduce the same run via CLI using a 'Copy CLI command' button.
UI performance stays smooth during long runs.

phases.name: Scale to Top-100+ Coins via Coin Packs
phases.objective: Extend coverage without turning the engine into spaghetti: add coins by data + small adapters.
deliverables: Coin-pack schema v1 finalized + pack compiler/validator tool
Built-in pack: EVM family + major UTXO variants + select ed25519 chains
Pack import/export and versioning
Automated conformance tests per coin definition
tasks: Map top-100 coins into families: EVM, UTXO-secp256k1, ed25519, others
Implement adapter hooks for non-standard address schemes
Add CI that runs conformance tests for all coin packs
acceptance_criteria: Adding a new EVM chain requires only metadata (name/ticker) — no code.
Adding a new UTXO coin requires only version/HRP parameters — no code.
Non-standard chains are isolated behind explicit adapters.

phases.name: Packaging, Signing, Updates, and Release Process
phases.objective: Make it feel like a real product shipped by adults: reproducible builds, signing, and safe updates.
deliverables: Windows installer (MSI or NSIS/Inno) with GPU runtime detection
Code signing plan (EV cert optional) and CI/CD release pipeline
Portable mode option
Optional auto-update channel (signed updates) for future
acceptance_criteria: Fresh Windows machine install works without manual dependency fiddling.
GPU detection is reliable and failure modes are clear and non-scary.

commands.name: generate

commands.purpose: Benchmark available backends/devices for a chain and store a profile.

commands.purpose: List supported chains/coins from installed coin packs.

commands.name: validate-pattern
commands.purpose: Validate pattern rules for a chain/address type.

unit_tests: Crypto primitives: keccak, sha256, ripemd160, pbkdf2
Pattern engine correctness: prefix/suffix/contains/regex, case rules
property_tests: Distribution sanity checks: hit-rate approximates expected probability over large samples
gpu_tests: Kernel correctness vs CPU reference for small batches
Deterministic match extraction and cancellation behavior
Cross-device regression suite (NVIDIA + AMD where available)
golden_vectors: Known private keys producing known addresses for BTC/EVM
Known checksum cases for EVM vanity patterns

key_handling: Use OS CSPRNG; never roll your own RNG
Zeroize key material in memory where feasible
Avoid writing private keys to disk unless user explicitly exports
Encrypted export option (password-derived key, modern KDF)
safe_mode: Offer split-key / seed+offset modes for demos and paranoid users
Clearly mark advanced modes; default to simplest safe path

how_to_run_phases_with_agents: Assign one agent per phase; lock acceptance criteria before coding.
Require agents to output: (1) code changes, (2) tests, (3) short 'how to run' notes, (4) benchmark numbers.
Gate merges on test pass + deterministic output schema conformance.

agent_prompt_template.title: Phase {PHASE_ID}: {PHASE_NAME}
prompt_body: Implement ONLY the deliverables listed for this phase.
Do not change the JSON export schema unless explicitly instructed.
Add tests for every new module; include golden vectors.
Provide a short benchmark run output and how to reproduce it.
List risks/unknowns discovered and propose mitigations without scope creep.

notes: Upstream README documents puzzle-mode (-Z/-l) and split-key workflow with keyconv (-P / PrivkeyPart recombination).
README indicates GPU is enabled by default and can be disabled via --no-gpu; supports regex patterns and multiple formats.
Archived upstream; treat as reference + test vectors, not a dependency.
Safe-by-design: does not generate a final key; adjusts user-provided public key; final privkey = seed_priv + offset.

verification_policy.principle: Repo READMEs are treated as the source of truth for 'expected behavior' as-of the verification date.
implementation_guidance: When using any upstream code as a build dependency, pin to a specific commit SHA or release tag.
For GPL/AGPL repos, treat as reference/test vectors; implement clean-room to avoid copyleft contagion unless the whole project is intentionally open-sourced.

zip_source_gap_analysis.analysis_goal: Identify feature gaps between the current game plan and the bundled zip sources, and record concrete additions needed for parity or security coverage.

missing_features.feature: Wildcard prefix matching ("?" and "*") for prefix searches.
missing_features.why_it_matters: Allows flexible prefix searches similar to VanitySearch behavior.
missing_features.how_to_add: Extend the pattern engine with a lightweight wildcard matcher for prefix mode only; keep regex behind Advanced. Add CLI validation for wildcard-only patterns.

missing_features.feature: Case-insensitive prefix matching toggle.
missing_features.why_it_matters: Parity with VanitySearch -c flag and user expectations from BTC tools.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add a case-insensitive flag to pattern engine; for base58/bech32, preserve case rules by chain/address type.

missing_features.feature: Compressed vs uncompressed address search modes, plus “both” mode.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch exposes -u and -b flags; users expect control over compressed/uncompressed key formats.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add address-type variants or a compression toggle in BTC/LTC adapters; expose in CLI and Advanced GUI.

missing_features.feature: Batch prefix list search + stop when all prefixes are found.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch supports -i inputfile and -stop to solve multiple patterns in one run.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add a batch pattern file input to CLI; implement stop condition once all patterns are satisfied; add GUI upload for pattern lists.

missing_features.feature: Explicit output file for results.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch supports -o outputfile for deterministic result storage.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add --results-file option in CLI and a “save results” control in GUI that writes JSON or text logs.

missing_features.feature: Manual GPU grid/workgroup override and device listing.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch exposes -g for grid size and -l to list devices for tuning.
missing_features.how_to_add: Expose GPU device listing in CLI/GUI and allow an Advanced override for batch size/workgroup dimensions with safety warnings.

missing_features.feature: Kernel self-check comparing GPU vs CPU results.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch -check validates GPU correctness; important for trust and support.
missing_features.how_to_add: Implement a self-test command that runs a small deterministic batch on CPU and GPU and compares outputs.

missing_features.feature: Rekey interval control for long-running sessions.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch -r allows rekeying for operational hygiene and performance stability.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add a scheduler option to rotate base keys at a configurable interval, with stats continuity handling.

missing_features.feature: Key utility commands: compute public key from private key and generate keypairs.
missing_features.why_it_matters: VanitySearch includes -cp and -kp; helpful for split-key workflows and validation.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add CLI subcommands for key inspection and keypair generation with consistent export formats.

missing_features.feature: EVM contract vanity address mode as a first-class option.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanitygen++ supports -F contract; contract vanity is a common EVM use case.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add a “contract address” mode for EVM that hashes sender+nonce(0) and matches against the derived contract address.

missing_features.feature: Key conversion utility (keyconv) parity.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanitygen++ ships keyconv for pubkey generation and split-key recombination.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add CLI subcommands for key conversion and split-key recombination to mirror keyconv workflows.

missing_features.feature: Explicit security warnings and UX guardrails against unsafe RNG-based generators.
missing_features.why_it_matters: The original profanity is explicitly insecure and archived; OmniVanity should clearly warn users and avoid similar pitfalls.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add a security notice in docs/UI explaining why old profanity is unsafe; ensure default RNG uses OS CSPRNG and block any deterministic/insecure modes unless explicitly marked “unsafe”.

missing_features.feature: Safe-mode requiring a seed public key and returning an offset private key (seed+offset design).
missing_features.why_it_matters: profanity2/3 safe-by-design workflow lets untrusted machines search without exposing final private keys.
missing_features.how_to_add: Implement an EVM safe-mode that takes a seed public key, searches for an offset, and provides a safe recombination utility.

missing_features.feature: Hex-pattern scoring modes (zeros, letters, numbers, mirror, leading-doubles).
missing_features.why_it_matters: profanity3 provides non-prefix scoring modes that users may expect for EVM vanity generation.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add advanced scoring modes to pattern engine for EVM-only hex output; surface in Advanced UI and CLI flags.

missing_features.feature: Range-based hex matching (leading-range and anywhere-range) with min/max controls.
missing_features.why_it_matters: Useful for probabilistic patterns and vanity constraints beyond fixed strings.
missing_features.how_to_add: Extend EVM matcher to support range constraints and validate min/max inputs in CLI.

missing_features.feature: Benchmark-only mode and device/kernel controls (skip device, no-cache, work sizes).
missing_features.why_it_matters: Power users need device tuning and cache control when using OpenCL-based engines.
missing_features.how_to_add: Expose device skip, kernel cache toggle, and workgroup sizing controls in Advanced settings; add a quick benchmark mode that doesn’t search.

missing_features.feature: Audit/crack mode for legacy profanity1 keys (risk assessment tool).
missing_features.why_it_matters: profanity3 includes a mode to assess compromised keys; useful for migration guidance.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add an “audit legacy vanity keys” tool that checks if a given public key is from a known-weak generator and recommends replacement.

missing_features.feature: Solana (ed25519) vanity support with prefix/suffix matching.
missing_features.why_it_matters: solVanityPlus focuses on Solana; OmniVanity should track ed25519-family needs.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add an ed25519 chain adapter and a Solana address encoder; wire prefix/suffix matching with base58 rules.

missing_features.feature: OpenCL GPU backend for ed25519 with multi-GPU support.
missing_features.why_it_matters: solVanityPlus demonstrates OpenCL acceleration and multi-GPU scaling for Solana.
missing_features.how_to_add: Plan an OpenCL backend for ed25519 similar to the secp256k1 pipeline; add device selection and multi-GPU scheduling.

missing_features.feature: Device selection and iteration-bits tuning for GPU throughput.
missing_features.why_it_matters: solVanityPlus exposes device selection and an iteration-bits performance knob.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add Advanced tuning controls for ed25519 batch sizes (iteration bits) and explicit device selection.

missing_features.feature: Case-sensitive toggle and multiple prefixes per run.
missing_features.why_it_matters: solVanityPlus allows multiple prefixes and case sensitivity control in Solana searches.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add per-chain case-sensitivity controls where it’s valid and allow multiple prefix inputs in batch mode.

missing_features.feature: Multi-result output (count) and output directory selection.
missing_features.why_it_matters: Users often want multiple vanity keys and organized output.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add “count” and “output directory” options to CLI and export panel for batch result writing.

missing_features.feature: Manager/orchestrator workflow (optional distributed execution).
missing_features.why_it_matters: solVanityPlus includes a manager and a GCP Pub/Sub example for coordinating workers.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add an optional orchestration mode that can distribute pattern jobs to worker nodes, with JSON job definitions and result aggregation.

missing_features.feature: Browser-based generator + offline-first usage.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanity-btc demonstrates a web UI that runs fully offline; aligns with normie UX expectations.
missing_features.how_to_add: Consider a web companion or offline-capable UI mode for simple CPU vanity generation with clear offline messaging.

missing_features.feature: User-controlled thread count in UI.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanity-btc exposes thread controls for performance tuning in constrained environments.
missing_features.how_to_add: Expose a threads slider in Advanced settings and tie it to the CPU worker pool size.

missing_features.feature: Reveal-private-key gating in UI.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanity-btc hides private keys until the user explicitly reveals them.
missing_features.how_to_add: Add an explicit “Reveal private key” action that is disabled by default until a match is found.

missing_features.feature: Desktop Electron app packaging option for offline use.
missing_features.why_it_matters: vanity-btc ships an Electron desktop app; some users may prefer a simple offline app.
missing_features.how_to_add: Keep Tauri as primary, but document an optional lightweight offline build (or port simple mode to a webview-only package) if needed.
